episodes.title: Forest Benedict Returns, The Power of Internal Family Systems | Ep 70 | Moral Combat
episodes.description:
In episode 70 of the Moral Combat Podcast, Forest Benedict, a licensed marriage and family therapist (LMFT) with a specialization in religious trauma and Internal Family Systems (IFS) therapy, shares an enlightening discussion on his transition from a Christian sex addiction therapist to embracing a broader understanding of healing through IFS. Forest opens up about his personal healing journey, which was significantly impacted by psychedelics, leading him to discover IFS therapy—a method that emphasizes understanding and healing the various 'parts' of ourselves that have developed in response to trauma. By accessing one's authentic core self, characterized by compassion, courage, and clarity, individuals can offer wounded parts of themselves the safety needed to heal. Forest discusses the profound impact this approach has had on his life, particularly through inner child work and re-experiencing past traumas from a place of compassion. He touches on the complex nature of religious trauma, highlighting the persistence of survival behaviors long after leaving a religious context and the importance of developing self-trust and intuition. His reflections on how religious teachings may be shaped by the unhealed traumas of their authors, along with his appreciation for the courage shown by Nathaniel and Zach in addressing religious trauma through the podcast, add depth to the conversation. The hosts' gratitude for Forest's vulnerability and the safe space he creates through his own healing journey rounds out an episode that's not only professional and insightful but also deeply human and relatable.

Moral Combat is a podcast hosted by siblings Nathan and Zach Blaustone. Join them as they discuss their passion for music production, their experiences with religious trauma, and share some laughs along the way. With their unique perspectives and dynamic personalities, Nathan and Zach bring an engaging and entertaining take on a variety of topics. Our mission is to facilitate respectful conversations that promote growth, communication, healing, authenticity, and siblinghood. Tune in to Moral Combat for thought-provoking discussions and a good time.

episodes.title: Nick Vallentino, Ex-Calvary Chapel Pastor's Path to Clarity & Healing | Ep 69 | Moral Combat
episodes.description:
In episode 69 of the Moral Combat Podcast, Nick Vallentino recounts his tumultuous journey from being a pastor's kid entrenched in the Calvary Chapel community, through the escalation of his personal and professional life crises, to his path toward healing from severe religious trauma. Raised in a devout family, Nick's life took a pivotal turn following a car accident that led to his expulsion from Bible College, propelling him into ministry work in Puerto Rico and later, to leading a burgeoning church in Phoenix. However, beneath the surface of these achievements, Nick battled with anxiety, panic attacks, and a failing marriage, culminating in a divorce that cost him his pastoral position and severed ties with his mentor. Facing intense shame, anger, and diagnosed with PTSD, Nick embarked on a healing journey, leveraging therapy, plant medicine, and cannabis. His realization of his father's abusive behavior and the subsequent estrangement from his family marked a significant turning point. Nick's commitment to sharing his story and supporting others through their religious trauma underscores the episode, offering hope and validation to those navigating the challenging process of deconstruction. His approach emphasizes listening, validating experiences, and providing a non-judgmental space for healing, showcasing a deeply human narrative of resilience and redemption.

Moral Combat is a podcast hosted by siblings Nathan and Zach Blaustone. Join them as they discuss their passion for music production, their experiences with religious trauma, and share some laughs along the way. episodes.description:
In this deeply moving segment of the Moral Combat Podcast, the hosts and Julia Myers delve into the heart of religious trauma, focusing on the silent struggles of children and individuals ensnared in evangelical families. They share a poignant reflection on their own experiences of feeling hopeless and lost within the confines of their faith. Julia offers heartfelt advice to those navigating the turbulent waters of doubt and healing from religious trauma, emphasizing the importance of self-trust and the recognition of one’s inherent goodness. Through tears and genuine concern, this conversation extends a compassionate hand to listeners, encouraging them to honor and trust themselves amidst the journey of recovery and self-discovery.

episodes.title: Navigating Grief and Rejecting Harmful Theologies | From Ep 68 | Moral Combat
episodes.description:
This profound segment captures Julia Myers' intense period of grief and the subsequent disillusionment with the theological explanations offered by her religious community. Facing back-to-back tragedies, including the loss of a pregnancy, her mother-in-law's terminal diagnosis, and her father's death, Julia confronts the inadequacy and trauma of the spiritual narratives surrounding loss and suffering she was provided. Her raw and honest recounting of the moment she decided to disassociate herself from any group that aligns with a God who inflicts suffering for glory provides a powerful insight into the journey of redefining faith and finding peace beyond traditional religious doctrines.

episodes.title: Redefining Normal: Discovering Healthy Family Dynamics | From Ep 68 | Moral Combat
episodes.description:
In this revealing clip, Julia Myers shares a pivotal moment that challenged her understanding of normal family dynamics. Growing up in a strict environment where physical discipline was commonplace, Julia's perspective shifts dramatically when she encounters a partner whose childhood experience was strikingly different. His reaction to her casual mention of being disciplined opens her eyes to a world where healthy, non-violent parenting is not only possible but normal. This segment explores the profound impact of witnessing emotionally healthy relationships and reevaluates the definition of normalcy within family life, highlighting the possibility of nurturing without fear or harm.

episodes.title: Breaking the Mold of Purity Culture | From Ep 68 | Moral Combat
episodes.description:
In this poignant episode of the Moral Combat Podcast, Julia Myers recounts her harrowing experience with the expectations of purity culture within the Calvary Chapel community, including a nearly coerced betrothal. Julia's narrative takes us through her intense internal struggle as she faces societal and familial pressures to conform to a predestined marital arrangement, based on another's claim of divine instruction. Rejecting this path marked a pivotal moment in Julia's journey, leading to alienation from her community but also toward self-empowerment and the eventual meeting of her husband. This segment explores Julia's transition from the restrictive norms of her upbringing to embracing a more inclusive and loving expression of faith, showcasing her resilience and the transformative power of listening to one's inner voice amidst external coercion.

episodes.title: Curfew Confrontations: Challenging Authority at Calvary Chapel College | From Ep 68 | Moral Combat
episodes.description:
In this enlightening episode of the Moral Combat Podcast, Julia Myers recounts a pivotal moment of defiance against the strict curfew rules at Calvary Chapel Bible College. After inadvertently breaking the curfew by mere seconds, Julia faces disciplinary action, leading to a confrontation with the dean that challenges the institution's authoritarian measures. This segment captures Julia's growing disillusionment with the college's rigid control over students' lives, reflecting her courage to question and push back against unnecessary constraints. It's a story of empowerment, resilience, and the beginning of Julia's journey to break free from the college's overbearing rules, highlighting her determination to advocate for herself and others within the confines of a restrictive educational system.

episodes.title: Unveiling the Cult of Calvary Chapel College | From Ep 68 | Moral Combat
episodes.description:
In this revealing episode of the Moral Combat Podcast, Julia Myers shares her transformative journey at Calvary Chapel Bible College, where gendered roles deeply influenced both curriculum and expectations. Julia narrates how assignments differentiated by gender led her to question the institution's teachings and her place within them. A critical turning point arrives through her interactions with colleagues at Starbucks, who gently challenge her beliefs and ultimately reveal the college's cult-like nature. This conversation becomes a catalyst for Julia's deep introspection and the start of her path toward deconstruction and self-discovery. It's a story of confronting uncomfortable truths, finding support in unexpected places, and the power of intuition in navigating one's faith and identity.

episodes.title: Julia Myers, Deconstructing Christianity & Escaping Calvary Chapel
episodes.description: Julia shares a deeply personal narrative of growing up under the stringent doctrines of a conservative Calvary Chapel, leading to a profound journey of faith deconstruction and healing from religious trauma. Her story, marked by questioning rigid church teachings, navigating the complexities of relationships within a faith-based context, and experiencing significant personal losses, highlights the challenging path towards spiritual and emotional liberation. Julia's transformative journey is further enriched by her research on religious trauma's impact on sexuality and her pursuit of psychology to aid others in similar struggles. Despite facing gender inequality and the stifling of her voice within the church, Julia finds support in her husband, a pastor who respects her deconstruction journey. This episode encapsulates the essence of resilience, the importance of setting boundaries, and the pursuit of a spirituality that aligns with one's true self, offering solace and encouragement to others facing the daunting task of rebuilding their lives after religious trauma. Youtube Video Podcast Moral Combat, hosted by siblings Nathan and Zach Blaustone, is a heartfelt exploration of life's complexities, with a primary focus on healing from religious trauma. episodes.title: Confronting Abandonment & Betrayal After Leaving The Faith | From Ep 65 | Moral Combat
episodes.description:
In this intense episode of the Moral Combat Podcast, Kim Shambaugh delves into her harrowing experiences following her divorce. She recounts being stalked by her ex-husband's acquaintance, a preacher's kid, who sent chilling night vision photos of her residence. Kim also shares the distressing ordeal of her yard sale sabotage and the stark realization that her community, including those she once considered family, chose the church over her. Her journey highlights the painful yet eye-opening truth about conditional support and the harsh realities she faced for not conforming to the church's expectations. This clip is a raw and powerful testament to Kim's strength in navigating through betrayal and abandonment during a pivotal moment in her life.

In Episode 65 of the Moral Combat Podcast, hosts Zach and Nathan Blaustone delve into a deep conversation with guest Kim Shambaugh, exploring the impact of religious upbringing on personal growth and healing. Raised in an evangelical Baptist family, Kim's early life was dominated by purity culture and strict religious norms. Her journey, marked by a challenging marriage and struggles with perfectionism and eating disorders, led to a transformative divorce at 26 and subsequent ostracization from her church. Finding love and acceptance with her non-religious husband, Kim moved to Ohio, where she began deconstructing her faith and embracing practices like meditation and intuitive work. Her story culminates in founding Never Settle Life, a company focused on holistic nutrition and transformation, reflecting her journey towards self-discovery and healing.

episodes.title: Embracing Identity & Love Beyond Trauma | From Ep 63 | Moral Combat
episodes.description:
In this revealing episode of the Moral Combat Podcast, Jonathan Garza shares his deeply personal journey of growing up in the Seventh Day Adventist (SDA) church, a life thoroughly intertwined with its doctrines and community. From a young age, Jonathan found himself questioning the church’s claim to hold the complete biblical truth, a skepticism that grew as he matured. His story takes a poignant turn with his parents' divorce, an event that, as a church leader's child, brought him embarrassment and a sense of needing to hide the truth. College years brought a significant personal revelation as Jonathan first identified as bisexual, only to temporarily retreat into the closet, under the pressure of his religious upbringing. Eventually, Jonathan fully embraced his identity as a gay man, a decision that led to a gradual but definitive distancing from the Adventist church, catalyzed by the conflicting narratives of being gay and Christian. This transition wasn't without its challenges; Jonathan lost many relationships from his church community but maintained a close, albeit complex, bond with his mother. Her gradual acceptance, though not complete affirmation, of his sexuality highlights a journey marked by struggles with perfectionism, sexual repression, and a deep-seated need for external validation - all legacies of his religious upbringing. This episode poignantly captures Jonathan's struggle to reconcile his faith and sexuality, navigating external judgments and internal conflicts, while nurturing the enduring love between him and his mother.

Full Podcast Episode: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rqxJSRkMxgw

episodes.title: The Controversial Path to Spiritual Enlightenment | From Ep 62 | Moral Combat
episodes.description:
In Episode 62 of the Moral Combat Podcast, hosts Zach and Nathan open up about their journey from a strict evangelical Christian upbringing to finding their own spiritual paths. They share their experiences with leaving the church, the resultant feelings of loss and emptiness, and how they have since embraced alternative spiritual practices. Their candid discussions touch on the healing power of meditation, gratitude, and plant medicines like cannabis and psychedelics, and how these have helped them redefine their spiritual lives. The episode highlights the importance of community and support in their journeys, and also features a playful Nintendo gaming session, showcasing their approach to balancing deep introspection with lighthearted joy.

episodes.description:
Moral Combat is a podcast hosted by siblings Nathan and Zach Blaustone. Join them as they discuss their passion for music production, their experiences with religious trauma, and share some laughs along the way. With their unique perspectives and dynamic personalities, Nathan and Zach bring an engaging and entertaining take on a variety of topics. Our mission is to facilitate respectful conversations that promote growth, communication, healing, authenticity, and siblinghood. Tune in to Moral Combat for thought-provoking discussions and a good time.

episodes.title: The Unspoken Trauma of Church Induced Sexual Repression | Ep 58 | Moral Combat
episodes.description: In the thought-provoking Episode 58 of The Moral Combat Podcast, brothers Nathan and Zachary engage in a profound dialogue delving into the intricate topic of sexual repression, a haunting echo of their religious upbringing. Drawing from personal experiences, they unveil moments of intense shame and guilt surrounding their sexuality, shedding light on the profound impact of these experiences. The hosts navigate through biblical verses and teachings that explicitly endorse sexual repression, and explore how this repression reverberated through their romantic relationships and self-identities. This candid conversation serves as a healing process, providing clarity and a platform for self-acceptance in the face of deep-seated sexual guilt, ultimately advocating for a path toward liberation from the shadows of religious trauma. Moral Combat, hosted by siblings Nathan and Zach Blaustone, is a heartfelt exploration of life's complexities, with a primary focus on healing from religious trauma. Step into their world as they navigate the realms of music production, confront the lingering echoes of religious trauma, and embrace laughter as a universal healer. With each episode, Nathan and Zach weave together their unique perspectives, seasoned with dynamic personalities that make every discussion an engaging adventure. From unraveling the complexities of personal growth to fostering open communication, healing the scars of religious indoctrination, and embracing the unfiltered authenticity of siblinghood, Moral Combat is your passport to thought-provoking conversations, heartfelt insights, and the pure joy of shared moments. Join us in the combat for morality, one conversation at a time. Moral Combat: Youtube Tiktok Instagram Twitter Facebook More Zach SYNZ More Nathan (They are a secret...)

episodes.title: Confronting the Traumas of Church and Parental Expectations | Ep 57 | Moral Combat
episodes.description: In the emotionally charged Episode 57 of The Moral Combat Podcast, brothers Nathan and Zachary delve into the intricate and deeply personal topic of guilt, an enduring legacy of their religious trauma rooted in their evangelical Christian upbringing. This poignant discussion unravels the ways in which the church ingeniously employed guilt as a tool to wield control over their behaviors and thoughts. The narrative unfolds as they recount their struggles with a pervasive sense of inherent sinfulness and unworthiness, perpetuated by the church's unwavering emphasis on morality and repentance, a toxic blend that bred guilt like wildfire. Doubt and questioning, once taboo within the church's confines, evolved into sources of profound guilt, further stifling their quest for personal truth. The hosts candidly share the debilitating guilt that shrouded their exploration of sexuality and purity, particularly surrounding the deeply intimate issue of masturbation. Adding to this complex tapestry of trauma, their roles as pastor's kids thrust them into the unforgiving spotlight of the church's expectations for evangelism and outreach, a burden that only amplified their guilt. This lingering guilt, an enduring shadow of their religious past, seeped into their post-evangelical lives, casting a long shadow over their relationships and mental well-being. Yet, in the cocoon of their podcast, Nathan and Zachary unearth the power of vulnerability and open conversation, forging a path toward healing and ultimately finding solace in the embrace of gratitude. This episode delves into the intricate web of guilt woven by the evangelical church during their childhood, its far-reaching ramifications, and the resilience borne from these candid dialogues as the brothers journey toward healing. Moral Combat, hosted by siblings Nathan and Zach Blaustone, is a heartfelt exploration of life's complexities, with a primary focus on healing from religious trauma. Step into their world as they navigate the realms of music production, confront the lingering echoes of religious trauma, and embrace laughter as a universal healer. With each episode, Nathan and Zach weave together their unique perspectives, seasoned with dynamic personalities that make every discussion an engaging adventure. From unraveling the complexities of personal growth to fostering open communication, healing the scars of religious indoctrination, and embracing the unfiltered authenticity of siblinghood, Moral Combat is your passport to thought-provoking conversations, heartfelt insights, and the pure joy of shared moments. episodes.title: Unpacking The Trauma Of Christian Rituals | Ep 56 | Moral Combat
episodes.description: In the thought-provoking 56th episode of The Moral Combat Podcast, brothers Nathan and Zach embark on a profound exploration of the trauma inflicted by religious rituals within the evangelical Christian framework. Drawing upon their shared upbringing in a devout Christian household, the hosts engage in a candid conversation that spans a wide spectrum of rituals inherent to their religious past. They traverse the emotional terrain of their experiences, from the uplifting and spiritual nature of rituals such as worship through music and prayer, to the unsettling and, at times, manipulative aspects found in rituals like communion and altar calls. This introspective journey takes a poignant turn as they reflect upon the evolution of their relationship with these rituals since departing from evangelical Christianity. In this newfound perspective, prayer transitions from a coerced conversation with a divine entity to a personal and introspective dialogue. Moreover, the hosts delve into the intriguing phenomenon of rituals migrating from a religious context into their secular lives, offering a rich insight into the enduring influence of these practices. In sum, this episode provides a compelling and authentic exploration of the profound impact of rigid religious rituals and their enduring consequences, offering a unique vantage point on the path from trauma to healing. Moral Combat, hosted by siblings Nathan and Zach Blaustone, is a heartfelt exploration of life's complexities, with a primary focus on healing from religious trauma. Step into their world as they navigate the realms of music production, confront the lingering echoes of religious trauma, and embrace laughter as a universal healer. episodes.title: Public Pool Exorcisms & Corrupt Christian Vets | Ep 55 | Moral Combat
episodes.description: In Episode 55 of The Moral Combat Podcast, hosts Nathan and Zach embark on a thought-provoking journey as they dive into Reddit posts centered around the theme of religious trauma. The episode unfolds with the hosts' empathetic exploration of these digital narratives, beginning with a poignant tale of someone whose neurological disorder was attributed to their departure from an abusive religious family, shedding light on the tendency of some Christians to attribute illnesses to a perceived lack of faith. The conversation shifts to a post inquiring about whether to reveal one's loss of belief to their family, with Nathan and Zach offering nuanced advice, drawing from their own experiences of coming out as non-believers within devout Christian households. Delving further into the Reddit realm, they encounter anecdotes about Christians conducting baptisms and exorcisms at a community pool, provoking discomfort among residents, leading to lighthearted musings on potential distractions. Additional posts broach sensitive topics like a veterinarian soliciting church visits after euthanizing a pet and the contentious issue of Christians prioritizing prayers over medicine in life-threatening situations. Amidst these discussions, the episode embraces moments of humor, empathy, and personal reflection while offering practical guidance for navigating complex family dynamics as individuals who have transitioned away from religious faith. The episode culminates with a spirited Mario Kart competition between Nathan and Zach, blending thoughtful analysis with entertaining gameplay. Moral Combat, hosted by siblings Nathan and Zach Blaustone, is a heartfelt exploration of life's complexities, with a primary focus on healing from religious trauma. episodes.title: Jesus Camp Is Malicious!!! & Block Fort 3.0 | Ep 47 | Moral Combat
episodes.description: In episode 47 of the Moral Combat podcast, the hosts, brothers Nathan and Zach, delve into the sensitive topic of religious trauma and healing. They open with Nathan's nervous anticipation of his first acting class. The conversation takes a thought-provoking turn as they explore the impact of an evangelical Christian documentary, "Jesus Camp," which follows children attending an intense religious summer camp. Given their own religious upbringing, the documentary proves triggering, as they share disturbing clips of kids being indoctrinated and speaking in tongues, evoking memories of their own experiences with brainwashing at church camps. Seeking solace, they transition to a competitive session of Mario Kart 64, a nostalgic escape from their past church traumas. The episode concludes with a vow to revisit the documentary's themes in future episodes, acknowledging its significance in addressing the religious trauma both they and others have endured.
